paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Preclinical pooled mouse experiments testing intratumoral mRNA vaccine combined with anti-PD-L1 therapy for tumor control.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort (single agents and vehicle)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched pooled mouse controls including vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle, used to assess null and conditional effects.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort on ICI
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective metastatic patient cohort receiving immune checkpoint inhibitor treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

major_limitations: Human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
